articles.headline: Mutual Frustrations Arise in U.S.-Ukraine Alliance
articles.snippet: Ukrainian officials are disheartened about stalled aid. The Pentagon wants Kyiv to heed its advice on how to fight.
articles.abstract: Ukrainian officials are disheartened about stalled aid. The Pentagon wants Kyiv to heed its advice on how to fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than two years into their wartime alliance, the bond between the United States and Ukraine is showing signs of wear and tear, giving way to mutual frustration and a feeling that the relationship might be stuck in a bit of a rut.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

articles.headline: TikTok Prompts Users to Call Congress to Fight Possible Ban
articles.snippet: Many Capitol Hill offices were inundated with phone calls after TikTok urged users to tell their representatives they opposed a new bill aimed at the company.
articles.abstract: Many Capitol Hill offices were inundated with phone calls after TikTok urged users to tell their representatives they opposed a new bill aimed at the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Washington lawmakers introduced a bill this week calling for TikTok to cut ties with its Chinese parent company or face a ban in the United States. When many users opened the popular app on Thursday, the company greeted them with a message to oppose the legislation, prompting a flood of phone calls to several Capitol Hill offices.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and David McCabe

articles.headline: Key OpenAI Executive Played a Pivotal Role in Sam Altman’s Ouster
articles.snippet: Mira Murati, OpenAI’s chief technology officer, brought questions about Mr. Altman’s management to the board last year before he was briefly ousted from the company, people familiar with the matter said.
articles.abstract: Mira Murati, OpenAI’s chief technology officer, brought questions about Mr. Altman’s management to the board last year before he was briefly ousted from the company, people familiar with the matter said.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than three months after OpenAI’s board of directors briefly ousted Sam Altman, the chief executive of the high-profile artificial intelligence company, questions remain about exactly what led the board to make such a dramatic move.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac, Tripp Mickle and Cade Metz

articles.headline: Offering a Choice of ‘Revenge’ vs. ‘Decency,’ Biden Strikes a Contrast With Trump
articles.snippet: The president made it clear in a State of the Union address that he sees the election as an existential struggle between democracy and extremism.
articles.abstract: The president made it clear in a State of the Union address that he sees the election as an existential struggle between democracy and extremism.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden used his State of the Union address on Thursday to launch a series of fiery attacks against former President Donald Trump, a competitor whom he did not mention by name but made clear was a dire threat to American democracy and stability in the world.

articles.headline: ‘Decolonizing’ Ukrainian Art, One Name-and-Shame Post at a Time
articles.snippet: Oksana Semenik’s social media campaign both educates the curious about overlooked Ukrainian artists — and pressures global museums to relabel art long described as Russian.
articles.abstract: Oksana Semenik’s social media campaign both educates the curious about overlooked Ukrainian artists — and pressures global museums to relabel art long described as Russian.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hiding for days in the basement of a kindergarten in Bucha, the Kyiv suburb that became synonymous with Russian war crimes, Oksana Semenik had time to think.

articles.headline: In-Your-Face Biden Takes on Trump and His Own Doubters
articles.snippet: In a raucous State of the Union address, the president’s goal was to reassure Americans that at 81 he is ready for a second term. He made his case, loudly and forcefully.
articles.abstract: In a raucous State of the Union address, the president’s goal was to reassure Americans that at 81 he is ready for a second term. He made his case, loudly and forcefully.
articles.lead_paragraph: This was not Old Man Joe. This was Forceful Joe. This was Angry Joe. This was Loud Joe. This was Game-On Joe.

articles.headline: Trump’s Man at the R.N.C. Will Face Pressure to Satisfy His Election Lies
articles.snippet: The former president believes his pick to lead the Republican National Committee, Michael Whatley, is more in sync with his views about voter fraud than Ronna McDaniel, whom he succeeded on Friday.
articles.abstract: The former president believes his pick to lead the Republican National Committee, Michael Whatley, is more in sync with his views about voter fraud than Ronna McDaniel, whom he succeeded on Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the 2020 election, one story out of North Carolina had a powerful effect on Donald J. Trump.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Berzon, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: The Oscars Now Have D.E.I. Rules, but Some Say It’s Just a Performance
articles.snippet: How “Oppenheimer,” a movie about the men who developed the atomic bomb, met the new standards.
articles.abstract: How “Oppenheimer,” a movie about the men who developed the atomic bomb, met the new standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates for the 2024 Oscars.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: U.S. Employers Add 275,000 Jobs in Another Strong Month
articles.snippet: Economists are trying to gauge whether forecasts of a slowing labor market were mistaken or just premature. For now, gains are consistent and strong.
articles.abstract: Economists are trying to gauge whether forecasts of a slowing labor market were mistaken or just premature. For now, gains are consistent and strong.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the economy is slowing down, nobody told the labor market.
